item.title: lua programming trick for neovim scripting
item.description: TL;DR you can use ctags for go-to-definition and look for ideas of configuring, for example, the neovim lsp. You can’t do it with sumneko and other language servers for lua. The instruction of how is below. Introduction and lua I’d like to share the one trick for neovim programming. Recently I’ve found out that you can rewrite (almost) all your neovim scripting code to lua language. And it turns out to be the smallest and simplest language possible.

item.title: vim ijump command
item.description: Recently I’ve read a great article about moving around files in vim. The author says you could move between files faster with using :edit and :find commands. Also for :find one you should set include option or includeexpr func when imports of language are rather different from usual project structure. I don’t think the :find command is useful for Go programming since you should include $HOME/pkg/mod in path, and file searching become pretty slow at this point.

item.title: How to make a site using Hugo, Github Actions and pages
item.description: This site was build with hugo, Github Actions, markdown pages and a drop of love. Here is a couple of links I used: hugo is a static site generator, also see a quick start guide Github Actions is a CI/CD building blocks for Github Github Pages is a free hosting for static websites You can setup hugo with Github Actions and Pages using this link Posts can be edited as markdown documents, syntax cheatsheet is here To be loved you should be nice Also I replace --minify flag in my Actions file from the guide with -D, since the old command couldn’t generate new pages (UPD: -D == --buildDrafts, so you should not mark posts as drafts and everything will be OK with the default configuration)
